sub_title: Writer in Architecture and Art, Associate Professor Emeritus Theory in the Arts
summary:
I am an historian and a theorist in Architecture and Art. I write, lecture and teach about Architecture, Art and Urbanism from a cultural and a philosophical viewpoint. I published ten books and an uncountible number of articles, dealing with a.o. city and speed, the history of the industrial city and the architecture of  highways, parkways, airports, trainstations, hospitals and dwellings, including theories of design and making. 
My work strives for a more independant approach in Theory and History of Architecture and Art which I interpret as independant cultural disciplines with their own domain to that of the practising architects and artists.

treasury_media: [{'url': 'https://home.hccnet.nl/j.w.nijenhuis/artikel/DeDiabolischeSnelweg.html', 'title': 'De Diabolische Snelweg', 'description': "Autosnelwegen bepalen voor een groot deel het gezicht en de beleving van ons land. In De diabolische snelweg corrigeren theoreticus Wim Nijenhuis en architect Wilfried van Winden het hardnekkige misverstand dat de ontwerpers ervan alleen maar oog hadden voor verkeerstechniek en veiligheid, terwijl schoonheid hun eigenlijke doel was. Een vergeten Nederlandse ontwerptraditie wordt met foto's en essays gedocumenteerd ", 'image': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/sync/C5627AQEBTlaf_oVYKA/articleshare-shrink_800/0/1690893049616?e=1692939600&v=beta&t=GO-dTlCcD72PaHnxC7O8KrKLGdcYqA5Rxsrg022jXiw'}, {'url': 'https://www.uitgeverij1001.nl/book_44.html', 'title': 'THE RIDDLE OF THE REAL CITY ... , OR THE DARK KNOWLEDGE OF URBANISM', 'description': 'Does our knowledge about city and urban planning have solid ground? Can historical research promote creative thinking? How can we theorise about urban design and architecture in our age of the media? These questions have guided the guided the creation of this multi-layered, richly documented and illustrated triptych, in which the Dutch architectural theorist Wim Nijenhuis pursues a creative goal: to stimulate new ways of thinking in architectural culture. projects: [{'title': 'Het weerwoord van de materie/ The Response of Matter', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'In this forthcoming book I will relate the actual theory of making, as it is developed by architects, lecturers and theorists in the field of architecture, to the sociological and antropological theories of Richard Sennett and Peter Sloterdijk. I will confront the thinking about and within making as it has  largely been developed in practice, with the concepts of The Craftsman (2007) and You have to Change your Life (2009). \nThe aim of this confrontation is to enrich the discourse of architectural design with concepts that will change theory in such a way that it inevitably will change practice. Beside that I hope to inscribe the practice of making in the antropological practices of training and the making of a better man, a man that will be able to avoid the coming ecological catastrophe. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Wim', 'last_name': 'Nijenhuis', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Writer in Architecture and Art, Associate Professor Emeritus Theory in the Arts'}]}]

I am especially fond of the works in which I managed to bring history, theory of architecture and urbanism and philosophy to interference, as I it happened in my book: The Diabolical Highway (2007), and in my dissertation: A Cloud of Dark Knowledge (2003). 
In my articles I express my concern about the state of our urban culture in relation to the increasing influence of modern communication technology. Instead of progress, I witness a catastrophic history. Can we still speak of a city culture in the sense of the ancient Greeks and the Renaissance? We sincerely discussed the state and role of present day art that is so often forced to take on a practical function in urban projects. Finally we discussed the state of our society and the possible role of art: Can it (still) be critical? Can it (still) be critique? Is there (still) a possibility for critique? Do we have to focus again on religious and metaphysical themes, concerning discipline and selfconstraint, in order to overcome neo-liberalism?
